reviews.review_msg: Briefly had this prof at UBC during covid. Canvas site posted late, putting behind in my new class after dropping his joke of a class (but it all worked, anything works better than a class with *ucker). Some hate recorded lectures; for me, zoom or recorded = ok. But what's not, is no lectures, all just copied/pasted readings. And no office hours

She is intelligent and interested in her field of study, but she is extremely monotonous. I could not stay awake because of that. I wish she would be a little more interesting... the course content is so interesting, I think that's how I survived.
Her lectures were extremely interesting and the way she structured them made note taking extremely intuitive.  I highly recommend taking a class with her (although be prepared for low midterm marks).

Expect your average history course. The material was fairly easy but the marking was brutal. The marking scheme demanded more out of students than normal, which led to dismal mid-term marks. She wound up scaling up the class, but this is something to keep in mind. When you think you wrote enough, write some more!

The most passionate professor I've ever had! In her lectures, I never stopped writing notes like mad. She even had a way of making otherwise boring material interesting! Any history buff will love her as much as I did.
She was a great prof although sometimes her voice put me to sleep. I usually stayed awake though, and I learned a lot. Very friendly outside of the lecture hall as well.
She speaks in iambic pentameter. If you don't write notes it puts you to sleep. But if you take notes she's awesome. Her lectures are soooo interesting, especially when she talks about Germany.

I had her 2 years ago and I still think she is amazing.  She inspired me to be a history major.  If you can, take her.  She has the clearest lectures that are so full of information you will be writing like mad!  I can't stress enough how great of a prof she is and I'm lucky to have had her.
Wonderful prof who gets really into what she teaches.  She doesn't go off topic and is very good at what she does.  But her exam was a bit hard

Nadine is so incredibly passionate about history that it comes out in her voice - definitely kept me wide awake in class and writing notes like mad. She answers students' questions clearly and never goes off topic. My only complaint is that we had too much reading and it was sometimes hard to keep up, and my TA was a nightmare. Nadine is beautiful!

Nadine's lectures were awesome! She's very passionate about what she was teaching, even though it's a general "overview" type course.  Even though it was a large lecture she allowed questions and answered them with clear and concise answers. Assignments and tests are fair.

A very nice, approachable woman with a passion for what she is teaching. I definitely loved the class, but I was not happy with all of the guest lecturers that we had to suffer through (they were "auditioning" for a job with SFU) but at least the stuff they covered wasn't on the final!
did all the readings, attended all lectures and still got a B-, she is too hard for an intro course, I am in my fourth year! Don't recommend

Nadine is an inspiring orater.  Her lectures are interesting and she is passioniate when giving them.  Her marking is rather strict for a 1st year course, but Nadine is always open to discuss your grade as long as you have a good argument.  She is beautiful; sit up close if possible.

Her lectures are hard to follow because her headings are so long, by the time you have them copied down she's said 5 important things you missed. She loves and knows her history, but her voice is just annoying! It's almost a patronizing tone, or one used to sing songs. Nice lady though
Sooooo boring! She made history evil.

Evdoxios Doxiadis is a cool guy... seems really nice but lecture material failed to engage me.  Lecture slides have little info besides bullet points so you need to show up to class and listen.  Lots of reading for tutorials and weekly writing assignments.  Nothing unfair but you need to stay on top of this class... can be a challenge when bored.

Great lectures, super smart professor and clearly engaged in the material, yet somewhat unclear and contradictory guidelines for weekly responses and book reports. These issues were cleared up by the amazing TA we had. He was really engaging, passionate, accessible and knowledgeable. Oh... and hot which made going to weekly tutorials a breeze.

Quite knowledgeable about lecture material. Very helpful with answering questions and emails with plenty of detail. Helpful review sessions. Lecture quality and audio needs work. Exams(3 essays) were not realistic given with the typical 1st year workloads. Not clear with learning objectives. Slides need more words. Responses need more guidelines.

Have you ever wanted to take a course where your midterm and final are 10 page minimum 3 essay questions as if you don't have any other courses and the questions don't make sense? Do you hate feedback and prefer to not see any grades at all on Canvas till the end of the term? Take this amazing course and experience it all yourself!!

Terrible job creating lecture slides and teaching the material. This was a into level history class and it made it seem like a 3rd-4th year class. Will not recommend at all. Very picky grader and expects you to know more than the lecture. His lectures were just his audio with no effort with the slides. Terrible experience.
Absolutely horrible professor. He can't assign proper assignments with guidelines/criteria or reasonable midterms that's not 15 pages due in 1 week. He thinks we don't have lives or other classes.

Lectures are dry but he is very considerate for making sure that everyone can hear him (he uses a clip on mic). Many of the concepts I could relate back to courses in other disciplines so super useful. Sometimes he loses track of time and tries to quickly go through them in the last few minutes of lecture. However, he's always open to questions.

This class is extremely lecture heavy. There is no doubt that Aaron loves what he does, but PLEASE AVOID THIS CLASS. Every lecture ended 2 minutes late and occasionally tutorials ended really late too. he talks way too much and looses track of time. He would say last slide, but would rush the last 10 slides of lecture to get content through.

This professor needs to restructure his class. There is too many things to do on a weekly basis. He seems to believe that his class is the only one that matters. He blabbers during lecture without any real structure. He has very unclear grading criteria and makes it very difficult to get a decent grade

Aaron is a really nice guy. I do not agree at all with the comments critiquing his lectures; I was thoroughly captivated and thought he was great at storytelling. I found the readings extremely interesting and well-written. Ample hints were given in class as to what would be on the exams  the hardest part was always the multiple choice section.

As a non-history major, I found this class to be a fine choice for an elective. One lecture per week was very nice and participation being worth 20% of your grade was excellent. The readings (textbook and primary sources) were usually dull, with a few interesting tidbits here and there. Exams were not a cakewalk but also not impossible.
boring as heck man. lectures were so dull and test material came from the textbook.

Aaron is a great man and clearly he knows what he is talking about, but his lectures are unbearable. He is monotone and unfortunately his interests were not on par with mine with the course as he lectured mainly on artwork and nothing really much about the material in the txtbook. His tests are around 85% on what he lectures on

One of the best profs at SFU, this guy is super into history and always willing to chat during office hours and after class, even non-course stuff. I didn't have him this semester, and I went to ask him for a reference, and we talked for almost an hour about music and stuff! The class would be harder for non-history students, but probably worth it.
Amazing professor... Great lectures and generally a wonderful person to talk to. Would have loved if he taught the tutorial because he really is a wonderful professor

Lectures expand more on smaller details, but give a bigger picture than what's in the book. In-tutorial tests with little warning, so you really have to read the books carefully. Genuinely enjoys lecturing and the material. It's a very engaging class, but there is a lot of work involved.

Lectures- he often doesn't go over big ideas and talks about smaller details in class. This makes class interesting, but hard to follow. Read every word of the textbook more than once and study for exams long in advance and you will do well. Overall a good class, I just found lectures hard to follow and there is a lot of reading.

Windel is nice and very passionate about what he teachers. Lectures can be hard to follow sometimes. Read the whole textbook and you'll do well. Participation in tutorials is worth 25% so do the readings, attend class and speak up. Overall, and enjoyable, informative class

I found this course difficult as a 3rd year student. I can't imagine how it might have been for the 1st year students. The recorded lectures were in 6 parts about 20-30 minutes each every week. Overall, the grading was hard on the midterms. They want you to think critically based on time questions. This is not a GPA booster, you have to work hard!

Paul is a very good prof. His lectures are clear, structured, and efficient. Some may find him to be a little fast-paced though. HIST 106 grade was based on the midterm, final, and primary source analysis assignments (all done in class). Exams are fair but a little hard to prep for as he doesn't give specifics as to exactly what you'll be tested on
Tons of reading to do but he's very effective at teaching the topics. He's funny. Tutorials are hard though.

An absolutely fantastic professor -- one of the best at SFU. His lectures were clear and often funny, his exams and marking were fair, and tutorials were based on 3-4 short readings every week. Expectations were reasonable -- just learn how to make and defend an argument. Only drawback: my TA was horrendous, but I hear the other one was great.

He was an ok prof but don't take this course if you're not interested in history. Such an intense course and there is so much to know. The tutorials were absolutely brutal. Garfinkel always went OT and got a bit boring after the 2 hours of lecture... if you're majoring in history, you'll probably like this class though.
Outstanding professor. Has good lectures at a good pace and is the most prepared and approachable prof I've had.

A great intro course. This prof has an obvious passion for teaching and genuine concern for students. Lectures are clear and engaging (even if they run OT sometimes), office hours are helpful, and assignments are designed to help you succeed. Basically, you get everything you need, and the rest is up to you. I learned a lot and enjoyed the class.

Paul was a horrible teacher, His final was worth 50% and the class ranged from Fr. Revolution to the Berlin Wall, very brief and broad and horrible to compreend in a first year class. Way too much reading and tutorials were brutal. I would not recommend taking this class with him.
Go the point across during lecture, but was awful at managing his time; he seldom finished a class on time.

Agreed: Paul is a great prof. I look forward to taking more courses with him. He combines a no nonsense teaching style with good humour and fair marking. He also doesn't try to shove a particular point of view down your throat (unlike other history profs I've had).
Garfinkel is awesome.
very good prof and well prepared.. my only complaint is that he just flies through a ton of material each lecture and i dont think he even takes a breath
Great course! Garfinkel is an outstanding lecturer. The class is just hard enough to be challenging and easy enough to be fair. And who else uses Darth Vader and Jerry Garcia in powerpoint slides?
He was very amusing, at the right times, providing entertaining and witty remarks along with pictures, in colour many a time!
I agree: excellent professor, great class. Teh class got even better when Garfinkel took over tutorial. Really helps you if you're willing to help yourself.
My favourite history prof at SFU!

Great class, great professor! I liked 106 so much, I am taking another class with Garfinkel next term. Sad to say, it was the only class I enjoyed last term. I looked forward to every lecture. And it was great when he took over our tutorial from the useless TA. It was comedy hour, but we really got things done. Helped me big time for the final.

I can't say much for Garfinkel himself. Did not have him as a TA or go to his office hours, but he seemed like a nice guy and made a couple good jokes during class.  I wouldn't recommend taking this class in your first year. The grading scheme and exams are taylored a little more for second years.

A really nice guy witha good attitude. His lectures were always good because he keeps his pace up and uses point form exclusively. His mid term and final were "fair"...by no means easy and by no means horrible. His term paper though was a little sketchy. All in all  I enjoyed his class but this is NOT a GPA booster.

Garfinkel IS great! Loved this class. Prof is fair, funny, friendlty. Exams were a breeze, hardly unfair. Never noticed the "uhhh" stuff, but sounds like a disgruntled classmate looking to hate the prof for their own crappy marks. Enough spoonfeeding for first year students, and challenging enough for older ones. I recommend, but not a GPA booster.

Garfinkel? Not such a bad guy. However, his notes are really hard to follow but he likes to put up nice pictures. Hard to listen to what he says when every two seconds he says "UUUHHHH". His exams are rather unfair. A definition could possibily be worth 20marks. If you don't have to take this class don't.

Garfinkel is Great! He sends out study terms and questions every week, is exteremly organized in his lecture material and is very clear about what exams will consist of. There is so much content to cover in the course and he really tries to help his students out.
Garfinkle's great, but demanding.  Very interesting, very difficult as a TA.  Also very engaging.

The textbook is USELESS. Too much... 'waffle'. But if you took other EURO or world history before, this is almost just a review of it. So for me it was pretty easy and not a lot of studying. If you took HIST's before 1850-1980, would make your life a lot easier. If not, prepare to do a lot of memorizing. Got over 100 years to memorize =)
what a guy.  hate the exams, they were hard and unfair, but lectures interesting - you can tell he puts a lot of effort in, and is passionate about the subject.  its a mixed bag with this one.

v good prof. a real sweetie and cute goatee too. lectures are engaging and through but subject matter is not always so exciting. hes really passionate and cares about students. he doesnt have tutorials but is really approachable and helpful if you want to talk to him. i wish more profs were this nice.
Way cool prof. Clear lectures, dry humour, very helpful and thorough in office hours. Super nice guy if you get to know him. Not so sure about my TA tho.

this woman does not understand what a 100 level course is - she reads off these large essays which she has prepared for each class. demonstrating her lack of ability and knowledge of the info to just lecture using powerpoint. literally tells you her arguments and reads her essays. readings are unrealistic - more than a 300 level course.

Looking back at my degree now that I'm almost done, one of the best teachers I had while at SFU. Pushes students to think and question without being obnoxious or in-your-face. Cares about History, about learning, and about people. I enjoyed the class at the time, but really appreciate it now that's over.

There was a LOT of reading in this class, and as an Engineering student I wasn't used to this kind of Arts stuff: it was tougher than I was expecting. Professor Lanthier was the best part of the course, and he made the material clear and interesting. He expects a lot, but if you put in some real effort you'll be just fine.
Dr. Lanthier is a very nice prof and so chill. His tests and assignments are straightforward and he's an easy marker. Really enjoyed this class.
A lot of reading. I found this class hard, but others thought it was easy. A lot of info to know. He wants his students to do well and is a caring, passionate prof.

The first few weeks of this course was fine but after that, he started assigning two chapters a week. One chapter is already 35-40 pages long plus he makes you read 4-6 primary sources on top of the weekly readings. This class is very demanding and I wouldn't recommend taking it unless you have to. Good luck.

HIST 106 is a great first-year course for anybody in the Arts and Social Sciences--I just took it by accident in Surrey, but it's been really useful to have under my belt during my second year. Profesor Lanthier made the whole thing pretty painless and even fun. Yah, there's a lot of reading, but it's not as bad as other courses. Take it!

Good school, good class, good prof.  I enjoyed this more than I thought I would.  There was a lot of reading, and I wasn't really used to that, but Prof. Lanthier made it clear what we needed to know on the exams.  Lanthier's a nice guy, really approachable, and will give good advice on how to do well on assignemtns and test.

I hate the SFU class model where you have to take a tutorial with a bunch of bored people who didn't do the readings.  But that not Professor Lanthier's fault.  He did everything he could to make the experience pleasant.  The lectures were interesting and clear, the tutorials not too bad.  He told you exactly what you needed to know on the exams.

Very good at his job, and veyr respectful of all his students during discussions.  Does not give his own opinion all the time like some other SFU professors in the Arts, and that's important to me.  There was lot of reading in this class, maybe a little too much, but exams and essays are actually pretty easy so far.

Alright, so i took 106 with him about 2-3 years ago. Im almost done my history degree, and after spending time with a lot of other history profs, i realize how AWESOME Lanthier was. sorta creepy in tutorial when he looks at you, but good feedback, and overall the only class i never fell asleep in! You cant expect better than him! goodluck

Seriously... Waste of time. He seems to fear students and his lectures are irrelevant to the course material. I stopped listening to his lecture half way through the semester and my grades actual improved. DO NOT TAKE.

The lecture content was subpar at best. Instead of being European history it was primarily British and French history. He glossed over important issues but talked about trivial details for long amounts of time. Class itself was quite easy but he does show some personal bias in marking. The 20% participation was a huge mark booster.

By far the most horrendous teacher I've had in my entire life. It's depressing that students pay to be educated by people as incapable as this. He was not confident in the material at all and simply read (poorly) from a sheet of paper. Condescending to those who dared participate and uninterested in teaching. Knows NOTHING about how to convey info.

Worst instructor ive ever had, doesnt really know what hes talking about, all he says is "thats not my area of study". Reads off of his "notes" in class, they seem like a summary. Refuses to do any powerpoint at all. His marks seemed almost personal as there were so many ways to lose marks. Even went as far as to ridicule some students in tutorial.

Worst proffessor I have had so far, reads his notes off paper and does not post them online, very hard to follow in lecture at first. He seems to have no interest in teaching and even midly ridicules questions, and has little knowlege about the course subject. The only good thing is participation is 20%, so show up and talk.

seems like he just reads an essay of the topic.. he doesnt put his notes online so it is impossible to catch everything.. and is very spontaneous when it comes to marking, will take marks off for a number of personal reasons.

is being a professor means to read "notes" from a piece of paper for the whole semester??? his test are not that hard but u have to study a lot from the book and his notes, the only problem is that he reads his "notes" (I'd say a summarize from the book) way too fast and sometimes are pointless
Is unclear about his instructions and penalizes trivial things. Not his area of study and should not be teaching European history.
Not many slides, but explains in detail and encourage students to ask questions during the lectures. Sometimes speaks fast, but he is a very flexible prof.

Sukhjit was a good Prof, his lectures just really sucked. Course was graded by 3 Primary sources (2 written, 1 presentation), a pop quiz, and a final exam. Be prepared to type fast, he speaks very quick, and his slide shows do not convey a lot of information. He does take the time to answer questions which is good. Not very clear on grading.

Hilmar is an excellent professor. Yes, the way he grades is tough but he spells out his expectations very early in the course so there are no surprises. He also does not give final exams and his tests are not cumulative, so that means less work!

i took a course with him and thought he was  a great proff. i leart a lot and he was extremely entertaining and humourous. but i ended up with a crappy mark. the next semester i took another history course with him. just as funny and knowledgable, just as clear. he expects decent effort, and your grade will reflect how much you gave.

Giant glass ego! Every tutorial uncomfortably spent with everyone staring at the floor, avoiding eye contact while he played "guess what I'm thinking right now." Insecure to the point of unbalanced -- attacking the furniture, shouting at the class... What a nut!

If you're worried abour ruining your precious GPA, don't take a class with Professor Pabel. If you want to be educated (and actually learn a little bit about the world you live in), do take a class with Professor Pabel.

This man is nerdy, quirky, and snobby. He thinks he knows a lot, he is sure of himself, but he is a lousy social scientist. More importantly, he doesn't know how to mark papers. Stay away from this man and his courses. He will ruin your good GPA.
interesting class, but very, very hard
Nice guy, but his marking is ridiculously hard
Over-sensitive, close-minded

I think he doesn't really know about the course , and he is not fully prepared to lectures. He had never post anything on canvas, not even lecture slides &marks. Don't take it if you can't learn the course by yourself. Participation MATTERS.

lectures are really boring, slides were not engaging. Grading is heavy and she provided some backhanded comments on paper assignments when accidentally referred to something wrong. final was online and timed.

She gave very interesting lectures and answered any student questions. There were 3 small assignments, a midterm, final, and book review - all very fair, clear expectations given. Naz was an amazing TA, giving super helpful feedback on how to improve in the future. The weekly readings were long, but she was extremely kind - HIGHLY recommend her.

An excellent prof. He manages to  make history more exciting and hopefully more memorable.  He is taking a few semesters off to write a book, he will be missed.  The only downside was that there was a ton of reading to do for the course and the books were over priced especially the one by the SFU press, it was a really low budget print job.
